Federal Reserve Tone Decoder

Federal Reserve Tone Decoder: interpreting key Fed communications

As of 2026-01-10

Communications Interpretation Module

Fed Tone Decoder – Communications Interpretation Module.

Speaker: Chair Powell | Date: December 10, 2025 | Source: Press Conference

  • Labour Market: ✗ Gradually cooling, downside risks increased, job creation potentially negative.
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Somewhat elevated overall, but non-tariff inflation in the low 2s; risk of persistence due to tariffs is noted.
  • Policy Bias: Easing (25bps cut and initiation of short-term Treasury purchases)
  • Risk Asymmetry: Downside risks to employment remain primary concern, prompting policy adjustments.
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ Strongly differing views on future rate path; multiple dissents on current policy action.

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Policy easing focused on stabilizing the labor market amidst elevated inflation, with explicit acknowledgement of internal divisions.

Event: Rate Decision | Date: December 10, 2025

Policy Action: 25bps CUT

Context: Policy rate reduced in response to sustained downside risks to employment and to guide inflation back to target once tariff effects pass, aligning with a more neutral stance (6).

Speaker: FOMC | Date: December 10, 2025 | Source: Monetary Policy Implementation

  • Labour Market: Policy aims to stabilize the labor market, which is experiencing downside risks (6).
  • Inflation Concern: Measures to support disinflation are implicit in the policy adjustments (6).
  • Policy Bias: Easing (25bps cut in FFR, IORB, Primary Credit Rate) and initiation of short-term Treasury purchases to maintain ample reserves (6).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Policy adjusts to address employment risks while ensuring price stability (6).
  • Internal Divergence: ✗ Unanimous vote by Board of Governors for IORB and primary credit rate changes.

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Direct policy easing actions implemented, including rate cut and balance sheet adjustments for reserve management.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: December 9-10, 2025 | Source: Summary of Economic Projections

  • Labour Market: ✓ Downside risks to employment still elevated, with a majority expecting unemployment to be higher than projected (13 "Weighted to Upside" for U/E) (5).
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Upside risks to inflation remain for a majority (12 "Weighted to Upside" for PCE) (5).
  • Policy Bias: Future FFR path is unchanged from September, indicating continued gradual easing towards neutral (5).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Primary emphasis on mitigating downside risks to employment, despite persistent inflation risks (5).
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ Wide dispersion in FFR projections for 2025 and beyond (5).

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Projections reflect continued gradual easing, with significant concern for employment downside and notable committee division on future policy.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: December 10, 2025 | Source: FOMC Statement

  • Labour Market: ✗ Job gains slowed, unemployment rate edged up but remains low, downside risks to employment rose in recent months (6).
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Inflation moved up and remains somewhat elevated (6).
  • Policy Bias: Easing (1/4 percentage point cut) (6).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Downside risks to employment rose, while inflation remains somewhat elevated, prompting a balanced approach (6).
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ Three members dissented: S. Miran (preferred 1/2 percentage point reduction), A. Goolsbee, J. Schmid (preferred no change) (6).

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Rate cut and initiation of short-term Treasury purchases in response to rising employment risks, despite elevated inflation and notable dissent.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: November 2025 | Source: The Beige Book

  • Labour Market: ✗ Employment declined slightly, weakening labor demand, AI impacting entry-level positions (2).
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Prices rose moderately, widespread input cost pressures (tariffs, insurance, healthcare) (2).
  • Policy Bias: Data-dependent (report on current economic conditions) (0).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Increased risk of slower activity and financial strains on low/middle-income households (2).
  • Internal Divergence: ✗ Not applicable for Beige Book.

Behavioural Feasibility: HOLD-BIASED

TONE: NEUTRAL — Softening labor market and ongoing price pressures create a complex backdrop, with a slight tilt towards growth concerns.

Speaker: Chair Powell | Date: October 29, 2025 | Source: Press Conference

  • Labour Market: ✗ Gradually cooling, job gains slowed significantly, downside risks to employment risen.
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Somewhat elevated, goods inflation picked up (tariffs), services disinflation continues.
  • Policy Bias: Easing (25bps cut + early end to QT).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Balance of risks shifted, downside risks to employment risen (primary concern).
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ Strongly differing views about December meeting; two dissents on current policy.

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Policy easing focused on employment risks, with a strategic shift in balance sheet policy despite elevated inflation and internal disagreements.

Event: Rate Decision | Date: October 29, 2025

Policy Action: 25bps CUT

Context: Policy rate reduced and balance sheet reduction concluded to address increasing downside risks to employment (9). This is the second consecutive cut.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: October 29, 2025 | Source: Monetary Policy Implementation

  • Labour Market: Policy actions are responsive to downside risks to employment (9).
  • Inflation Concern: Policy aims to return inflation to 2 percent objective (9).
  • Policy Bias: Easing (25bps cut in FFR, IORB, Primary Credit Rate) and conclusion of QT (all principal payments reinvested into Treasury bills starting Dec 1) (9).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Downside risks to employment are explicitly highlighted as having risen (9).
  • Internal Divergence: ✗ Unanimous Board vote for IORB and primary credit rate changes.

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Direct policy easing actions implemented, including rate cut and a significant shift in balance sheet policy by concluding QT.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: October 29, 2025 | Source: FOMC Statement

  • Labour Market: ✗ Job gains slowed, unemployment rate edged up but remained low, downside risks to employment rose in recent months (9).
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Inflation moved up since earlier in the year and remains somewhat elevated (9).
  • Policy Bias: Easing (1/4 percentage point cut) and decision to conclude asset reduction (9).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Downside risks to employment rose (primary concern) (9).
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ Two members dissented: S. Miran (preferred 1/2 percentage point reduction), J. Schmid (preferred no change) (9).

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Rate cut and cessation of quantitative tightening signal a strong pivot towards supporting employment, despite ongoing inflation concerns and internal debate.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: October 28-29, 2025 | Source: Minutes

  • Labour Market: ✗ Labor market gradually softened, job gains slowed, downside risks to employment rose (8).
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Inflation moved up, remained elevated, core elevated, upside risks to inflation persist (8).
  • Policy Bias: Easing (majority favored a cut, conclusion of QT) (8).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Downside risks to employment rose, while inflation upside risks persist; policy is leaning towards employment (8).
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ Strongly differing views on future rate path (many favored cut, some no change, one 50bps cut) (8).

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Minutes reflect a consensus for easing policy (rate cut and ending QT) driven by increasing employment risks, despite persistent inflation concerns and a wide range of views.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: October 2025 | Source: The Beige Book

  • Labour Market: ✗ Employment stable but demand muted, some layoffs/attrition, supply strains in sectors (2).
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Prices rose further, input costs increased faster (tariffs, services), some expected acceleration in 2026 (2).
  • Policy Bias: Data-dependent (report on current economic conditions) (0).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Downside risk to growth from prolonged government shutdown; general elevated uncertainty (2).
  • Internal Divergence: ✗ Not applicable for Beige Book.

Behavioural Feasibility: HOLD-BIASED

TONE: NEUTRAL — Mixed economic activity with muted labor demand, rising input costs, and significant uncertainty, suggesting cautious monitoring.

Speaker: Chair Powell | Date: September 17, 2025 | Source: Press Conference

  • Labour Market: ✗ Unemployment edged up, job gains slowed significantly, downside risks to employment risen.
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Risen recently, somewhat elevated; near-term expectations up (tariffs), but longer-term anchored.
  • Policy Bias: Easing (25bps cut and moving towards a more neutral stance).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Balance of risks shifted, downside risks to employment risen (primary concern).
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ One member preferred a 50bps cut; some expressed merit in keeping rates unchanged.

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Policy easing motivated by significant softening in the labor market and a shift in the balance of risks towards employment concerns, despite ongoing elevated inflation.

Event: Rate Decision | Date: September 17, 2025

Policy Action: 25bps CUT

Context: Policy rate reduced in light of increased downside risks to employment and moderated economic activity (11).

Speaker: FOMC | Date: September 17, 2025 | Source: Monetary Policy Implementation

  • Labour Market: Policy aims to support maximum employment, given downside risks (11).
  • Inflation Concern: Policy aims to return inflation to 2% objective (11).
  • Policy Bias: Easing (25bps cut in FFR, IORB, Primary Credit Rate); continuation of balance sheet reduction (11).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Downside risks to employment explicitly rose, signaling a shift in the balance of risks (11).
  • Internal Divergence: ✗ Unanimous Board vote for IORB and primary credit rate changes.

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Direct policy easing via rate cut to address employment risks, while continuing balance sheet reduction.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: September 16-17, 2025 | Source: Summary of Economic Projections

  • Labour Market: ✓ Downside risks to employment increased; majority expects unemployment to be higher than projected (13 "Weighted to Upside" for U/E) (5).
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Upside risks to inflation remain for a majority (12 "Weighted to Upside" for PCE) (5).
  • Policy Bias: Significantly lower FFR path for 2026 and 2027 compared to June, indicating an easing bias (5).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Downside risks to employment and GDP are prominent (13 "Weighted to Downside" for GDP) (5).
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ Wide range of FFR projections (2.88% to 4.38% for 2025) (5).

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Projections signal a clear easing bias with reduced FFR path, driven by elevated employment and growth risks, alongside notable committee dispersion.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: September 17, 2025 | Source: FOMC Statement

  • Labour Market: ✗ Job gains slowed, unemployment rate edged up but remains low, downside risks to employment have risen (11).
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Inflation moved up and remains somewhat elevated (11).
  • Policy Bias: Easing (1/4 percentage point cut) and continued balance sheet reduction (11).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Committee attentive to risks on both sides, judges downside risks to employment have risen (primary concern) (11).
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ One member (S. Miran) voted against, preferring a 1/2 percentage point reduction (11).

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Rate cut implemented due to rising employment risks, despite elevated inflation, indicating a clear pivot towards easing, with some internal disagreement on magnitude.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: September 16-17, 2025 | Source: Minutes

  • Labour Market: ✗ Job gains slowed, unemployment rate edged up, labor market conditions softened, downside risks to employment tilted to the downside (10).
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Inflation somewhat elevated, tariff effects putting upward pressure, upside risks to inflation emphasized (10).
  • Policy Bias: Easing (almost all members supported a 25bps cut given shift in balance of risks) (10).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Risks to employment/labor market tilted to the downside, while inflation risks are skewed to the upside; explicit shift to employment risk (10).
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ One member voted against a 25bps cut, preferring 50bps, and a few had reservations about any cut (10).

Behavioural Feasibility: ACTION-BIASED

TONE: DOVISH — Minutes reveal a strong consensus for easing, driven by clear softening in the labor market and a notable shift in the balance of risks towards employment.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: August 22, 2025 | Source: Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy

  • Labour Market: ✓ Seeks maximum employment, recognizes employment may run above real-time assessments without creating price stability risks (14).
  • Inflation Concern: ✗ Reaffirms 2% inflation goal, prepared to act forcefully to ensure longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored (14).
  • Policy Bias: Data-dependent (balanced approach when objectives conflict, assessed regularly) (0).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Balanced approach to dual mandate; acknowledges potential for employment to run hot without inflation risks (0).
  • Internal Divergence: ✗ Not applicable for strategy statement.

Behavioural Feasibility: HOLD-BIASED

TONE: NEUTRAL — A strategic document reiterating commitment to dual mandate with a flexible, data-dependent approach and a balanced view on risks.

Event: Rate Decision | Date: July 30, 2025

Policy Action: HOLD

Context: Policy rate maintained as economic activity moderated, but labor market solid and inflation elevated (16).

Speaker: FOMC | Date: July 30, 2025 | Source: Monetary Policy Implementation

  • Labour Market: Labor market conditions solid (16).
  • Inflation Concern: Inflation remains somewhat elevated (16).
  • Policy Bias: Data-dependent (maintained FFR, continued QT) (16).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Attentive to risks on both sides of the dual mandate (16).
  • Internal Divergence: ✗ Unanimous Board vote for IORB and primary credit rate.

Behavioural Feasibility: HOLD-BIASED

TONE: NEUTRAL — Policy held steady with continued balance sheet reduction, reflecting a pause to assess incoming data amid solid labor and elevated inflation.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: July 30, 2025 | Source: FOMC Statement

  • Labour Market: ✓ Unemployment rate low and labor market conditions solid (16).
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Inflation remains somewhat elevated (16).
  • Policy Bias: Data-dependent (maintained FFR, will carefully assess incoming data for future adjustments) (16).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Attentive to risks to both sides of its dual mandate (balanced) (16).
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ Two members (Bowman, Waller) voted against, preferring a 1/4 percentage point reduction (16).

Behavioural Feasibility: HOLD-BIASED

TONE: NEUTRAL — Policy held steady as labor market remains solid, but inflation elevated. Forward guidance emphasizes data dependency and risk monitoring, with notable dissent from easing advocates.

Speaker: FOMC | Date: July 29-30, 2025 | Source: Minutes

  • Labour Market: ✓ Conditions solid, but some softening indicators (slowing job growth, rising U/E for some groups, immigration effects); low hiring and layoffs (15).
  • Inflation Concern: ✓ Disinflation stalled, inflation somewhat elevated, tariffs adding upward pressure, upside risks to inflation emphasized (15).
  • Policy Bias: Data-dependent (maintained FFR, agreed to continue QT, but market expects cuts) (15).
  • Risk Asymmetry: Majority viewed inflation upside as greater, but also noted downside risks to employment (15).
  • Internal Divergence: ✓ Two members dissented on maintaining rates, preferring a 25bps cut (15).

Behavioural Feasibility: HOLD-BIASED

TONE: NEUTRAL — Minutes indicate a cautious stance, holding rates amidst solid but possibly softening labor conditions, stalled disinflation, and a perceived greater upside risk to inflation by a majority, but with clear internal dissent.
